class="spacer-xsmall"></div><h3 class="heading-blog-related">SEO Poisoning and Fake PuTTY sites: Darktraceâs Investigation into the Oyster backdoor</h3><div class="spacer-xsmall"></div></div><div class="hide"><div class="text-size-small">SEO poisoning is a malicious tactic where threat actors manipulate search engine rankings to promote deceptive websites. These sites often mimic legitimate software downloads, delivering malware like the Oyster backdoor. Learn about Darktraceâs investigation into the tactics used to deliver Oyster via fake PuTTY sites and manipulate search visibility.</div></div></div><div class="margin-top-3 margin-small"><div class="blog35_author-wrapper"><div class="blog35_author-image-wrapper w-condition-invisible"><img loading="lazy" src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/667047738584635d6000dc0a_6191a88a1c0e39463c2bf022_placeholder-image.svg" alt="" class="blog35_author-image w-dyn-bind-empty"/></div><div class="blog_divider"></div><div class="blog35_author-text"><div class="text-size-tiny text-weight-semibold">Christina Kreza</div><div class="blog35_date-wrapper"><div class="text-size-tiny">Cyber Analyst</div></div></div></div></div><div class="spacer-xsmall"></div><a href="/de/blog/seo-poisoning-and-fake-putty-sites-darktraces-investigation-into-the-oyster-backdoor" class="w-inline-block"><div data-w-id="d2d68d34-4cde-8ecb-579e-3ae62a7cd079" class="button-group small-gap"><div class="button is-small">Read more</div><div class="blog-button-icon w-embed"><svg width="16" height="10" viewBox="0 0 21 17" fill="none" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
<path d="M12.8078 0.761963L20.202 8.15902V9.3502L12.8078 16.762L11.3554 15.3061L16.8277 9.82079H0V7.68843H16.8277L11.3554 2.20314L12.8078 0.761963Z" fill="#FF6B00"/>
</svg></div></div></a></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><section class="section_blogs-continued"><div class="padding-global"><div class="container-large"><div class="contiuned-blog-post-wrap hide"><div class="w-dyn-list"><div role="list" class="continue-reading-blogs-cl w-dyn-items"><div role="listitem" class="w-dyn-item"><div class="padding-section-small"><div class="blog-header"><div id="w-node-_6a4e4cbc-bd07-c860-591e-a3d80472f974-c9d8d661" class="blog-header-title"><div><div><div class="pixel-eyebrow_wrapper"><div class="icon-embed-custom w-embed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 8 8" fill="none" preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMid meet" aria-hidden="true" role="img">
<rect width="8" height="8" fill="currentColor"/>
</svg></div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">Blog</h2><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><h2 class="text-eyebrow w-dyn-bind-empty"></h2><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">October 15, 2025</h2><div class="eyebrow-reveal-div"></div></div><div class="spacer-small"></div></div></div><h2 class="heading-style-h2">How a Major Civil Engineering Company Reduced MTTR across Network, Email and the Cloud with Darktrace</h2></div><div id="w-node-_2561d5d9-fcb0-d673-7045-e0de5fb2172b-c9d8d661" class="blog-image-post-wrapper margin-0"><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68ee6b4edd4ebeea33617499_Civil%20Engineering%20photo.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="" sizes="100vw" srcset="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68ee6b4edd4ebeea33617499_Civil%20Engineering%20photo-p-500.jpg 500w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68ee6b4edd4ebeea33617499_Civil%20Engineering%20photo.jpg 800w" class="blog-header-image cover"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62d845d8a4c357036c43d980_Blog%20Post%20Image.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62ad3aca1401273fd522699d_Photo.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><div class="blog-image-overlay max-height-300"></div></div></div></div><div class="blog-article-grid"><div class="vertical align-left max-w-720 bottom-padding-40 bottom-border-grey"><div class="text-rich-text truncate is-blog w-richtext"><h2>Asking more of the information security team</h2><p>âWhat more can we be doing to secure the company?â is a great question for any cyber professional to hear from their Board of Directors. After successfully defeating a series of attacks and seeing the potential for AI tools to supercharge incoming threats, a UK-based civil engineering companyâs security team had the answer: Darktrace.</p><p>âWhen things are coming at you at machine speed, you need machine speed to fight it off â itâs as simple as that,â said their Information Security Manager. âThere were incidents where it took us a few hours to get to the bottom of what was going on. Darktrace changed that.â</p><p>Prevention was also the best cure. A peer organization in the same sector was still in business continuity measures 18 months after an attack, and the security team did not want to risk that level of business disruption.</p><h2>Legacy tools were not meeting the teamâs desired speed or accuracy</h2><p>The companyâs native SaaS email platform took between two and 14 days to alert on suspicious emails, with another email security tool flagging malicious emails after up to 24 days. After receiving an alert, responses often took a couple of days to coordinate. The team was losing precious time.</p><p>Beyond long detection and response times, the old email security platform was no longer performing: 19% of incoming spam was missed. Of even more concern: 6% of phishing emails reached usersâ inboxes, and malware and ransomware email was also still getting through, with 0.3% of such email-borne payloads reaching user inboxes.</p><h2>Choosing Darktrace</h2><p>âWhen evaluating tools in 2023, only Darktrace had what I was looking for: an existing, mature, AI-based cybersecurity solution. ChatGPT had just come out and a lot of companies were saying âAI thisâ and âAI thatâ. Then youâd take a look, and it was all rules- and cases-based, not AI at all,â their Information Security Manager. </p><p>The team knew that, with AI-enabled attacks on the horizon, a cybersecurity company that had already built, fielded, and matured an AI-powered cyber defense would give the security team the ability to fend off machine-speed attacks at the same pace as the attackers.</p><p>Darktrace accomplishes this with multi-layered AI that learns each organizationâs normal business operations. With this detailed level of understanding, Darktraceâs Self-Learning AI can recognize unusual activity that may indicate a cyber-attack, and works to neutralize the threat with precise response actions. And it does this all at machine speed and with minimal disruption.</p><p>On the morning the team was due to present its findings, the session was cancelled â for a good reason. The Board didnât feel further discussion was necessary because the case for Darktrace was so conclusive. The CEO described the Darktrace option as âan insurance policy we canât do withoutâ.</p><h2>Saving time with Darktrace / EMAIL</h2><p><a href="/de/products/email">Darktrace / EMAIL</a> reduced the discovery, alert, and response process from days or weeks to seconds . </p><p>Darktrace / EMAIL automates what was originally a time-consuming and repetitive process. The team has recovered between eight and 10 working hours a week by automating much of this process using / EMAIL. </p><p>Today, Darktrace / EMAIL prevents phishing emails from reaching employeesâ inboxes. The volume of hostile and unsolicited email fell to a third of its original level after Darktrace / EMAIL was set up.</p><h2>Further savings with Darktrace / NETWORK and Darktrace / IDENTITY</h2><p>Since its success with Darktrace / EMAIL, the company adopted two more products from the Darktrace ActiveAI Security Platform â <a href="/de/products/network">Darktrace / NETWORK</a> and <a href="/de/incident-readiness-recovery">Darktrace / IDENTITY</a>.</p><p>These have further contributed to cost savings. An initial plan to build a 24/7 SOC would have required hiring and retaining six additional analysts, rather than the two that currently use Darktrace, costing an additional Â£220,000 per year in salary. With Darktrace, the existing analysts have the tools needed to become more effective and impactful.</p><p>An additional benefit: Darktrace adoption has lowered the companyâs cyber insurance premiums. The security team can reallocate this budget to proactive projects. </p><h2>Detection of novel threats provides reassurance</h2><p>Darktraceâs unique approach to cybersecurity added a key benefit. The teamâs previous tool took a rules-based approach â which was only good if the next attack featured the same characteristics as the ones on which the tool was trained. </p><p>âDarktrace looks for anomalous behavior, and we needed something that detected and responded based on use cases, not rules that might be out of date or too prescriptive,â their Information Security Manager. âOur existing provider could take a couple of days to update rules and signatures, and in this game, speed is of the essence. Darktrace just does everything we need - without delay.â</p><p>Where rules-based tools must wait for a threat to emerge before beginning to detect and respond to it, Darktrace identifies and protects against unknown and novel threats, speeding identification, response, and recovery, minimizing business disruption as a result.</p><h2>Looking to the future</h2><p>With Darktrace in place, the UK-based civil engineering company team has reallocated time and resources usually spent on detection and alerting to now tackle more sophisticated, strategic challenges. Darktrace has also equipped the team with far better and more regularly updated visibility into potential vulnerabilities.</p><p>âOne thing that frustrates me a little is penetration testing; our ISO accreditation mandates a penetration test at least once a year, but the results could be out of date the next day,â their Information Security Manager. âDarktrace / Proactive Exposure Management will give me that view in real time â we can run it daily if needed - and thatâs going to be a really effective workbench for my team.â</p><p>As the company looks to further develop its security posture, Darktrace remains poised to evolve alongside its partner.</p></div><a href="/de/blog/how-a-major-civil-engineering-company-reduced-mttr-across-network-email-and-the-cloud-with-darktrace" class="horizontal align-center _20-column-gap hover-orange-underline w-inline-block"><div class="text-size-regular bold dark-orange">Continue reading</div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/6439504aac7642d452f73227_Orrange%20Arrow.svg" loading="eager" alt="" class="glossary-item-orange-arrow show"/></a></div><div id="w-node-d1366120-05a2-bfd5-a9b0-2be9d20c7ad6-c9d8d661" class="vertical align-left"><div class="heading-style-h6">About the author</div><div class="spacer-medium"></div><div class="horizontal _20-col-gap"><img src="" loading="lazy" alt="" class="_80-square new-box-shadow w-condition-invisible w-dyn-bind-empty"/><div><div class="text-size-large">The Darktrace Community</div><div class="spacer-xsmall"></div><div class="text-eyebrow w-dyn-bind-empty"></div></div></div></div></div></div><div role="listitem" class="w-dyn-item"><div class="padding-section-small"><div class="blog-header"><div id="w-node-_6a4e4cbc-bd07-c860-591e-a3d80472f974-c9d8d661" class="blog-header-title"><div><div><div class="pixel-eyebrow_wrapper"><div class="icon-embed-custom w-embed"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="100%" height="100%" viewBox="0 0 8 8" fill="none" preserveAspectRatio="xMidYMid meet" aria-hidden="true" role="img">
<rect width="8" height="8" fill="currentColor"/>
</svg></div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">Blog</h2><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">Network</h2><div class="text-eyebrow">/</div><h2 class="text-eyebrow">October 14, 2025</h2><div class="eyebrow-reveal-div"></div></div><div class="spacer-small"></div></div></div><h2 class="heading-style-h2">Inside Akiraâs SonicWall Campaign: Darktraceâs Detection and Response</h2></div><div id="w-node-_2561d5d9-fcb0-d673-7045-e0de5fb2172b-c9d8d661" class="blog-image-post-wrapper margin-0"><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e537e74e437e6ce8d05617_649aad0271e98100a829c173_GettyImages-1323108614.webp" loading="lazy" alt="akira sonicwall" sizes="100vw" srcset="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e537e74e437e6ce8d05617_649aad0271e98100a829c173_GettyImages-1323108614-p-500.webp 500w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e537e74e437e6ce8d05617_649aad0271e98100a829c173_GettyImages-1323108614-p-800.webp 800w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e537e74e437e6ce8d05617_649aad0271e98100a829c173_GettyImages-1323108614-p-1080.webp 1080w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e537e74e437e6ce8d05617_649aad0271e98100a829c173_GettyImages-1323108614-p-1600.webp 1600w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e537e74e437e6ce8d05617_649aad0271e98100a829c173_GettyImages-1323108614-p-2000.webp 2000w, https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e537e74e437e6ce8d05617_649aad0271e98100a829c173_GettyImages-1323108614.webp 2309w" class="blog-header-image cover"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62d845d8a4c357036c43d980_Blog%20Post%20Image.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff19cdd07d1258d49238d/62ad3aca1401273fd522699d_Photo.jpg" loading="lazy" alt="Default blog image" class="blog-header-image cover w-condition-invisible"/><div class="blog-image-overlay max-height-300"></div></div></div></div><div class="blog-article-grid"><div class="vertical align-left max-w-720 bottom-padding-40 bottom-border-grey"><div class="text-rich-text truncate is-blog w-richtext"><h2>Introduction: Background on Akira SonicWall campaign</h2><p>Between July and August 2025, security teams worldwide observed a surge in Akira ransomware incidents involving SonicWall SSL VPN devices [1]. Initially believed to be the result of an unknown zero-day vulnerability, SonicWall later released an advisory announcing that the activity was strongly linked to a previously disclosed vulnerability, CVE-2024-40766, first identified over a year earlier [2].</p><p>On August 20, 2025, Darktrace observed unusual activity on the network of a customer in the US. <strong>Darktrace detected a range of suspicious activity, including network scanning and reconnaissance, lateral movement, privilege escalation, and data exfiltration. </strong>One of the compromised devices was later identified as a SonicWall virtual private network (VPN) server, suggesting that the incident was part of the broader Akira ransomware campaign targeting SonicWall technology.</p><p>As the customer was subscribed to the <a href="https://www.darktrace.com/resources/darktrace-services-managed-detection-and-response">Managed Detection and Response (MDR) service,</a> Darktraceâs Security Operations Centre (SOC) team was able to rapidly triage critical alerts, restrict the activity of affected devices, and notify the customer of the threat. As a result, the impact of the attack was limited - approximately 2 GiB of data had been observed leaving the network, but any further escalation of malicious activity was stopped.</p><h2>Threat Overview</h2><h3>CVE-2024-40766 and other misconfigurations</h3><p>CVE-2024-40766 is an improper access control vulnerability in SonicWallâs SonicOS, affecting Gen 5, Gen 6, and Gen 7 devices running SonicOS version 7.0.1 5035 and earlier [3]. The vulnerability was disclosed on August 23, 2024, with a patch released the same day. Shortly after, it was reported to be exploited in the wild by Akira ransomware affiliates and others [4].</p><p>Almost a year later, the same vulnerability is being actively targeted again by the Akira ransomware group. In addition to exploiting unpatched devices affected by CVE-2024-40766, security researchers have identified three other risks potentially being leveraged by the group [5]:</p><figure style="max-width:409pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e5391b6e3c8f13a2ce9384_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.00.11%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div></figure><p>*The Virtual Office Portal can be used to initially set up MFA/TOTP configurations for SSLVPN users.</p><p>Thus, even if SonicWall devices were patched, threat actors could still target them for initial access by reusing previously stolen credentials and exploiting other misconfigurations.</p><h2>Akira Ransomware</h2><p><a href="https://www.darktrace.com/blog/akira-ransomware-how-darktrace-foiled-another-novel-ransomware-attack">Akira ransomware</a> was first observed in the wild in March 2023 and has since become one of the most prolific ransomware strains across the threat landscape [6]. The group operates under a Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) model and frequently uses double extortion tactics, pressuring victims to pay not only to decrypt files but also to prevent the public release of sensitive exfiltrated data.</p><p>The ransomware initially targeted Windows systems, but a Linux variant was later observed targeting VMware ESXi virtual machines [7]. In 2024, it was assessed that Akira would continue to target ESXi hypervisors, making attacks highly disruptive due to the central role of virtualisation in large-scale cloud deployments. Encrypting the ESXi file system enables rapid and widespread encryption with minimal lateral movement or credential theft. The lack of comprehensive security protections on many ESXi hypervisors also makes them an attractive target for ransomware operators [8].</p><h3>Victimology</h3><p>Akira is known to target organizations across multiple sectors, most notably those in manufacturing, education, and healthcare. These targets span multiple geographic regions, including North America, Latin America, Europe and Asia-Pacific [9].</p><figure style="max-width:2192pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e684a90c107be86fa5c2e0_Screenshot%202025-10-08%20at%207.53.20%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt="Geographical distribution of organizationâs affected by Akira ransomware in 2025 [9]."/></div><figcaption>Figure 1: Geographical distribution of organizationâs affected by Akira ransomware in 2025 [9].</figcaption></figure><h3>Common Tactics, Techniques and Procedures (TTPs) [7][10]</h3><p><strong>Initial Access</strong><br/>Targets remote access services such as RDP and VPN through vulnerability exploitation or stolen credentials.</p><p><strong>Reconnaissance</strong><br/>Uses network scanning tools like SoftPerfect and Advanced IP Scanner to map the environment and identify targets.</p><p><strong>Lateral Movement</strong><br/>Moves laterally using legitimate administrative tools, typically via RDP.</p><p><strong>Persistence</strong><br/>Employs techniques such as Kerberoasting and pass-the-hash, and tools like Mimikatz to extract credentials. Known to create new domain accounts to maintain access.</p><p><strong>Command and Control</strong><br/>Utilizes remote access tools including AnyDesk, RustDesk, Ngrok, and Cloudflare Tunnel.</p><p><strong>Exfiltration</strong><br/>Uses tools such as FileZilla, WinRAR, WinSCP, and Rclone. Data is exfiltrated via protocols like FTP and SFTP, or through cloud storage services such as Mega.</p><h2>Darktraceâs Coverage of Akira ransomware</h2><figure style="max-width:1736pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e539bbc8266e2f30eb06f9_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.02.59%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div></figure><h3>Reconnaissance</h3><p>Darktrace first detected of unusual network activity around 05:10 UTC, when a desktop device was observed performing a network scan and making an unusual number of DCE-RPC requests to the endpoint mapper (epmapper) service. Network scans are typically used to identify open ports, while querying the epmapper service can reveal exposed RPC services on the network.</p><p>Multiple other devices were also later seen with similar reconnaissance activity, and use of the Advanced IP Scanner tool, indicated by connections to the domain advanced-ip-scanner[.]com.</p><h3>Lateral movement</h3><p>Shortly after the initial reconnaissance, the same desktop device exhibited unusual use of administrative tools. Darktrace observed the user agent âRuby WinRM Clientâ and the URI â/wsmanâ as the device initiated a rare outbound Windows Remote Management (WinRM) connection to two domain controllers (REDACTED-dc1 and REDACTED-dc2). WinRM is a Microsoft service that uses the WS-Management (WSMan) protocol to enable remote management and control of network devices.</p><p>Darktrace also observed the desktop device connecting to an ESXi device (REDACTED-esxi1) via RDP using an LDAP service credential, likely with administrative privileges.</p><h3>Credential access</h3><p>At around 06:26 UTC, the desktop device was seen fetching an Active Directory certificate from the domain controller (REDACTED-dc1) by making a DCE-RPC request to the ICertPassage service. Shortly after, the device made a Kerberos login using the administrative credential.</p><figure style="max-width:2272pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e539f609dfdfefc5de598e_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.03.58%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 3: Darktraceâs detection of the of anomalous certificate download and subsequent Kerberos login.</figcaption></figure><p>Further investigation into the deviceâs event logs revealed a chain of connections that Darktraceâs researchers believe demonstrates a credential access technique known as âUnPAC the hash.â</p><p>This method begins with pre-authentication using Kerberosâ Public Key Cryptography for Initial Authentication (PKINIT), allowing the client to use an X.509 certificate to obtain a Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT) from the Key Distribution Center (KDC) instead of a password.</p><p>The next stage involves User-to-User (U2U) authentication when requesting a Service Ticket (ST) from the KDC. Within Darktrace&#x27;s visibility of this traffic, U2U was indicated by the client and service principal names within the ST request being identical. Because PKINIT was used earlier, the returned ST contains the NTLM hash of the credential, which can then be extracted and abused for lateral movement or privilege escalation [11].</p><figure style="max-width:1062pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e53a2b5e9394d5a5cbebb7_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.04.43%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt="Flowchart of Kerberos PKINIT pre-authentication and U2U authentication [12]."/></div><figcaption>Figure 4: Flowchart of Kerberos PKINIT pre-authentication and U2U authentication [12]</figcaption></figure><figure style="max-width:1381pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68ed3626004d9abfd94687dc_Akirascreenshot.png" loading="lazy" alt=""/></div><figcaption>Figure 5: Device event log showing the Kerberos Login and Kerberos Ticket events</figcaption></figure><p>Analysis of the desktop deviceâs event logs revealed a repeated sequence of suspicious activity across multiple credentials. Each sequence included a DCE-RPC ICertPassage request to download a certificate, followed by a Kerberos login event indicating PKINIT pre-authentication, and then a Kerberos ticket event consistent with User-to-User (U2U) authentication.</p><p>Darktrace identified this pattern as highly unusual. Cyber AI Analyst determined that the device used at least 15 different credentials for Kerberos logins over the course of the attack.</p><p>By compromising multiple credentials, the threat actor likely aimed to escalate privileges and facilitate further malicious activity, including lateral movement. One of the credentials obtained via the âUnPAC the hashâ technique was later observed being used in an RDP session to the domain controller (REDACTED-dc2).</p><h3>C2 / Additional tooling </h3><p>At 06:44 UTC, the domain controller (REDACTED-dc2) was observed initiating a connection to temp[.]sh, a temporary cloud hosting service. Open-source intelligence (OSINT) reporting indicates that this service is commonly used by threat actors to host and distribute malicious payloads, including ransomware [13].</p><p>Shortly afterward, the ESXi device was observed downloading an executable named âvmwaretoolsâ from the rare external endpoint 137.184.243[.]69, using the user agent âWget.â The repeated outbound connections to this IP suggest potential command-and-control (C2) activity.</p><figure style="max-width:1708pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e53a8ea01e348d5a62a6c3_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.06.31%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt="Cyber AI Analyst investigation into the suspicious file download and suspected C2 activity between the ESXI device and the external endpoint 137.184.243[.]69."/></div><figcaption>Figure 6: Cyber AI Analyst investigation into the suspicious file download and suspected C2 activity between the ESXI device and the external endpoint 137.184.243[.]69.</figcaption></figure><figure style="max-width:2172pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e53ae5304f84a4192967db_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.07.53%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt="Packet capture (PCAP) of connections between the ESXi device and 137.184.243[.]69."/></div><figcaption>Figure 7: Packet capture (PCAP) of connections between the ESXi device and 137.184.243[.]69.</figcaption></figure><h3>Data exfiltration</h3><p>The first signs of data exfiltration were observed at around 7:00 UTC. Both the domain controller (REDACTED-dc2) and a likely SonicWall VPN device were seen uploading approximately 2 GB of data via SSH to the rare external endpoint 66.165.243[.]39 (AS29802 HVC-AS). OSINT sources have since identified this IP as an indicator of compromise (IoC) associated with the Akira ransomware group, known to use it for data exfiltration [14].</p><figure style="max-width:1442pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e53b26d90343a0a6ab3bb2_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.09.02%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt="Cyber AI Analyst incident view highlighting multiple unusual events across several devices on August 20. Notably, it includes the âUnusual External Data Transferâ event, which corresponds to the anomalous 2 GB data upload to the known Akira-associated endpoint 66.165.243[.]39."/></div><figcaption>Figure 8: Cyber AI Analyst incident view highlighting multiple unusual events across several devices on August 20. Notably, it includes the âUnusual External Data Transferâ event, which corresponds to the anomalous 2 GB data upload to the known Akira-associated endpoint 66.165.243[.]39.</figcaption></figure><h2>Cyber AI Analyst</h2><p>Throughout the course of the attack, Darktraceâs Cyber AI Analyst autonomously investigated the anomalous activity as it unfolded and correlated related events into a single, cohesive incident. Rather than treating each alert as isolated, Cyber AI Analyst linked them together to reveal the broader narrative of compromise. This holistic view enabled the customer to understand the full scope of the attack, including all associated activities and affected assets that might otherwise have been dismissed as unrelated.</p><figure style="max-width:2142pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e53b5d915cf405d38bfa05_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.09.56%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt="Overview of Cyber AI Analystâs investigation, correlating all related internal and external security events across affected devices into a single pane of glass."/></div><figcaption>Figure 9: Overview of Cyber AI Analystâs investigation, correlating all related internal and external security events across affected devices into a single pane of glass.</figcaption></figure><h2>Containing the attack</h2><p>In response to the multiple anomalous activities observed across the network, Darktrace&#x27;s Autonomous Response initiated targeted mitigation actions to contain the attack. These included:</p><ul role="list"><li>Blocking connections to known malicious or rare external endpoints, such as 137.184.243[.]69, 66.165.243[.]39, and advanced-ip-scanner[.]com.</li><li>Blocking internal traffic to sensitive ports, including 88 (Kerberos), 3389 (RDP), and 49339 (DCE-RPC), to disrupt lateral movement and credential abuse.</li><li>Enforcing a block on all outgoing connections from affected devices to contain potential data exfiltration and C2 activity.</li></ul><figure style="max-width:2356pxpx" class="w-richtext-align-fullwidth w-richtext-figure-type-image"><div><img src="https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/626ff4d25aca2edf4325ff97/68e53b9f1ad355f5a8eb2e1e_Screenshot%202025-10-07%20at%209.11.04%E2%80%AFAM.png" loading="lazy" alt="Autonomous Response actions taken by Darktrace on an affected device, including the blocking of malicious external endpoints and internal service ports."/></div><figcaption>Figure 10: Autonomous Response actions taken by Darktrace on an affected device, including the blocking of malicious external endpoints and internal service ports.</figcaption></figure><h3>Managed Detection and Response</h3><p>As this customer was an MDR subscriber, multiple Enhanced Monitoring alertsâhigh-fidelity models designed to detect activity indicative of compromiseâwere triggered across the network. These alerts prompted immediate investigation by Darktraceâs SOC team.</p><p>Upon determining that the activity was likely linked to an Akira ransomware attack, Darktrace analysts swiftly acted to contain the threat. At around 08:05 UTC, devices suspected of being compromised were quarantined, and the customer was promptly notified, enabling them to begin their own remediation procedures without delay.</p><h2>A wider campaign? </h2><p>Darktraceâs SOC and Threat Research teams identified at least three additional incidents likely linked to the same campaign. All targeted organizations were based in the US, spanning various industries, and each have indications of using SonicWall VPN, indicating it had likely been targeted for initial access.</p><p>Across these incidents, similar patterns emerged. In each case, a suspicious executable named âvmwaretoolsâ was downloaded from the endpoint 85.239.52[.]96 using the user agent âWgetâ, bearing some resemblance to the file downloads seen in the incident described here. Data exfiltration was also observed via SSH to the endpoints 107.155.69[.]42 and 107.155.93[.]154, both of which belong to the same ASN also seen in the incident described in this blog: S29802 HVC-AS. Notably, 107.155.93[.]154 has been reported in OSINT as an indicator associated with Akira ransomware activity [15]. Further recent Akira ransomware cases have been observed involving SonicWall VPN, where no similar executable file downloads were observed, but SSH exfiltration to the same ASN was. These overlapping and non-overlapping TTPs may reflect the blurring lines between different affiliates operating under the same RaaS.</p><h2>Lessons from the campaign</h2><p>This campaign by Akira ransomware actors underscores the critical importance of maintaining up-to-date patching practices. Threat actors continue to exploit previously disclosed vulnerabilities, not just zero-days, highlighting the need for ongoing vigilance even after patches are released. It also demonstrates how misconfigurations and overlooked weaknesses can be leveraged for initial access or privilege escalation, even in otherwise well-maintained environments.</p><p>Darktraceâs observations further reveal that ransomware actors are increasingly relying on legitimate administrative tools, such as WinRM, to blend in with normal network activity and evade detection. In addition to previously documented Kerberos-based credential access techniques like Kerberoasting and pass-the-hash, this campaign featured the use of UnPAC the hash to extract NTLM hashes via PKINIT and U2U authentication for lateral movement or privilege escalation.</p><p>Credit to Emily Megan Lim (Senior Cyber Analyst), Vivek Rajan (Senior Cyber Analyst), Ryan Traill (Analyst Content Lead), and Sam Lister (Specialist Security Researcher) </p><h2>Appendices</h2><p><strong>Darktrace Model Detections </strong></p><p>Anomalous Connection / Active Remote Desktop Tunnel</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Data Sent to Rare Domain</p><p>Anomalous Connection / New User Agent to IP Without Hostname</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Possible Data Staging and External Upload</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Rare WinRM Incoming</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Rare WinRM Outgoing</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Uncommon 1 GiB Outbound</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Unusual Admin RDP Session</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Unusual Incoming Long Remote Desktop Session</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Unusual Incoming Long SSH Session</p><p>Anomalous Connection / Unusual Long SSH Session</p><p>Anomalous File / EXE from Rare External Location</p><p>Anomalous Server Activity / Anomalous External Activity from Critical Network Device</p><p>Anomalous Server Activity / Outgoing from Server</p><p>Anomalous Server Activity / Rare External from Server</p><p>Compliance / Default Credential Usage</p><p>Compliance / High Priority Compliance Model Alert</p><p>Compliance / Outgoing NTLM Request from DC</p><p>Compliance / SSH to Rare External Destination</p><p>Compromise / Large Number of Suspicious Successful Connections</p><p>Compromise / Sustained TCP Beaconing Activity To Rare Endpoint</p><p>Device / Anomalous Certificate Download Activity</p><p>Device / Anomalous SSH Followed By Multiple Model Alerts</p><p>Device / Anonymous NTLM Logins</p><p>Device / Attack and Recon Tools</p><p>Device / ICMP Address Scan</p><p>Device / Large Number of Model Alerts</p><p>Device / Network Range Scan</p><p>Device / Network Scan</p><p>Device / New User Agent To Internal Server</p><p>Device / Possible SMB/NTLM Brute Force</p><p>Device / Possible SMB/NTLM Reconnaissance</p><p>Device / RDP Scan</p><p>Device / Reverse DNS Sweep</p><p>Device / Suspicious SMB Scanning Activity</p><p>Device / UDP Enumeration</p><p>Unusual Activity / Unusual External Data to New Endpoint</p><p>Unusual Activity / Unusual External Data Transfer</p><p>User / Multiple Uncommon New Credentials on Device</p><p>User / New Admin Credentials on Client</p><p>User / New Admin Credentials on Server</p><h3>Enhanced Monitoring Models</h3><p>Compromise / Anomalous Certificate Download and / Suspicious Network Scan Activity</p><p>Unusual Activity / Enhanced Unusual External Data Transfer</p><h3>Antigena/Autonomous Response Models</h3><p>Antigena / Network / External Threat / Antigena / Network / Insider Threat / Antigena Large Data Volume Outbound Block</p><p>Antigena / Network / Insider Threat / Antigena Network Scan Block</p><p>Antigena / Network / Insider Threat / Antigena Unusual Privileged User Activities Block</p><p>Antigena / Network / Manual / Quarantine Device</p><p>Antigena / Network / Significant Anomaly / Antigena Alerts Over Time Block</p><p>Antigena / Network / Significant Anomaly / Antigena Controlled and Model Alert</p><p>Antigena / Network / Significant Anomaly / Antigena Enhanced Monitoring from Client Block</p><p>Antigena / Network / Significant Anomaly / Antigena Enhanced Monitoring from Server Block</p><p>Antigena / Network / Significant Anomaly / Antigena Significant Anomaly from Client Block</p><p>Antigena / Network / Significant Anomaly / Antigena Significant Server Anomaly Block</p><p>Antigena / Network / Significant Anomaly / Repeated Antigena Alerts</p><h3>List of Indicators of Compromise (IoCs) <strong> </strong></h3><p>Â· Â  Â  Â 66.165.243[.]39 â IP Address â Data exfiltration endpoint</p><p>Â· Â  Â  Â 107.155.69[.]42 â IP Address â Probable data exfiltration endpoint</p><p>Â· Â  Â  Â 107.155.93[.]154 â IP Address â Likely Data exfiltration endpoint</p><p>Â· Â  Â  Â 137.184.126[.]86 â IP Address â Possible C2 endpoint</p><p>Â· Â  Â  Â 85.239.52[.]96 â IP Address â Likely C2 endpoint</p><p>Â· Â  Â  Â hxxp://85.239.52[.]96:8000/vmwarecli Â â URL â File download</p><p>Â· Â  Â  Â hxxp://137.184.126[.]86:8080/vmwaretools â URL â File download</p><h3>MITRE ATT&amp;CK Mapping </h3><p>Initial Access â T1190 â Exploit Public-Facing Application</p><p>Reconnaissance â T1590.002 â Gather Victim Network Information: DNS</p><p>Reconnaissance â T1590.005 â Gather Victim Network Information: IP Addresses</p><p>Reconnaissance â T1592.004 â Gather Victim Host Information: Client Configurations</p><p>Reconnaissance â T1595 â Active Scanning</p><p>Discovery â T1018 â Remote System Discovery</p><p>Discovery â T1046 â Network Service Discovery</p><p>Discovery â T1083 â File and Directory Discovery</p><p>Discovery â T1135 â Network Share Discovery</p><p>Lateral Movement â T1021.001 â Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol</p><p>Lateral Movement â T1021.004 â Remote Services: SSH</p><p>Lateral Movement â T1021.006 â Remote Services: Windows Remote Management</p><p>Lateral Movement â T1550.002 â Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash</p><p>Lateral Movement â T1550.003 â Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Ticket</p><p>Credential Access â T1110.001 â Brute Force: Password Guessing</p><p>Credential Access â T1649 â Steal or Forge Authentication Certificates</p><p>Persistence, Privilege Escalation â T1078 â Valid Accounts</p><p>Resource Development â T1588.001 â Obtain Capabilities: Malware</p><p>Command and Control â T1071.001 â Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols</p><p>Command and Control â T1105 â Ingress Tool Transfer</p><p>Command and Control â T1573 â Encrypted Channel</p><p>Collection â T1074 â Data Staged</p><p>Exfiltration â T1041 â Exfiltration Over C2 Channel</p><p>Exfiltration â T1048 â Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol</p><h3>References</h3><p>[1] <a <script>
const queryString = window.location.search;
  const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(queryString);
  const params = ['utm_campaign', 'utm_source', 'utm_content', 'utm_medium', 'utm_term', 'utm_id'];
  let url_additions = "";

  for (let param of params) {
    let paramData = urlParams.get(param) || localStorage.getItem(param) || "-";
    if (paramData) {
      if (paramData != "-") {
        url_additions += param + "=" + paramData + "&";
      }
      localStorage.setItem(param, paramData);

      // Select the form input by ID and set its value if it exists
      const inputElement = document.getElementById(param);
      if (inputElement) {
        inputElement.value = paramData;
      }
    }
  }

  url_additions = url_additions.slice(0, -1);  
  

const links = document.querySelectorAll('a');
links.forEach(link => {
    if ((link.href.includes('novalue') || link.href.includes('/virtual-innovation-launch')) && !link.href.includes('#')) {
        link.href = link.href + (link.href.includes('?') ? '&' : '?') + url_additions;
    }
});

    let countries = [ { "name": "", "code": "COUNTRY" }, { "name": "United Kingdom", "code": "GB" }, { "name": "United States", "code": "US" }, { "name": "Canada", "code": "CA" }, { "name": }, { "name": "Aland Islands", "code": "AX" }, { "name": "Curacao", "code": "CW" }, { "name": "Democratic Republic of the Congo", "code": "CD" }, { "name": "Jersey", "code": "JE" }, { "name": "Isle of "Sint Maarten", "code": "SX" }, { "name": "Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba", "code": "BQ" }, { "name": "South Sudan", "code": "SS" }, { "name": "Serbia and Montenegro", "code": "CS" }, { "name": "Saint Barthelemy", "code": "BL" } ]

    for(var c = 0; c<countries.length; c++) {
            if(c == 0){
        $('[id^='+whereto+']').append('<option value>' + countries[c].name + '</option>');

            }else{
        $('[id^='+whereto+']').append('<option value="' + countries[c].code + '">' + countries[c].name + '</option>');
            }
    }
}
 function addStates(whereto) {
    let states = [
      { "name": "", "code": "none" },
      { "name": "Alabama", "code": "AL" }, { "name": "Alaska", "code": "AK" }, { "name": "Arizona", "code": "AZ" },
      { "name": "Arkansas", "code": "AR" }, { "name": "California", "code": "CA" }, { "name": "Colorado", "code": "CO" },
      { "name": "Connecticut", "code": "CT" }, { "name": "Delaware", "code": "DE" }, { "name": "Florida", "code": "FL" },
      { "name": "Georgia", "code": "GA" }, { "name": "Hawaii", "code": "HI" }, { "name": "Idaho", "code": "ID" },
      { "name": "Illinois", "code": "IL" }, { "name": "Indiana", "code": "IN" }, { "name": "Iowa", "code": "IA" },
      { "name": "Kansas", "code": "KS" }, { "name": "Kentucky", "code": "KY" }, { "name": "Louisiana", "code": "LA" },
      { "name": "Maine", "code": "ME" }, { "name": "Maryland", "code": "MD" }, { "name": "Massachusetts", "code": "MA" },
      { "name": "Michigan", "code": "MI" }, { "name": "Minnesota", "code": "MN" }, { "name": "Mississippi", "code": "MS" },
      { "name": "Missouri", "code": "MO" }, { "name": "Montana", "code": "MT" }, { "name": "Nebraska", "code": "NE" },
      { "name": "Nevada", "code": "NV" }, { "name": "New Hampshire", "code": "NH" }, { "name": "New Jersey", "code": "NJ" },
      { "name": "New Mexico", "code": "NM" }, { "name": "New York", "code": "NY" }, { "name": "North Carolina", "code": "NC" },
      { "name": "North Dakota", "code": "ND" }, { "name": "Ohio", "code": "OH" }, { "name": "Oklahoma", "code": "OK" },
      { "name": "Oregon", "code": "OR" }, { "name": "Pennsylvania", "code": "PA" }, { "name": "Rhode Island", "code": "RI" },
      { "name": "South Carolina", "code": "SC" }, { "name": "South Dakota", "code": "SD" }, { "name": "Tennessee", "code": "TN" },
      { "name": "Texas", "code": "TX" }, { "name": "Utah", "code": "UT" }, { "name": "Vermont", "code": "VT" },
      { "name": "Virginia", "code": "VA" }, { "name": "Washington", "code": "WA" }, { "name": "West Virginia", "code": "WV" },
      { "name": "Wisconsin", "code": "WI" }, { "name": "Wyoming", "code": "WY" }
    ];
    
    // Populate the state dropdown
    for (var c = 0; c < states.length; c++) {
      if (c == 0) {
        $('[id=' + whereto + ']').append('<option value="-" selected>' + states[c].name + '</option>');
      } else {
        $('[id=' + whereto + ']').append('<option value="' + states[c].code + '">' + states[c].name + '</option>');
      }
    }
  }

  // Add states to any select with ID 'state' by default
  addStates('state');
  addCountries('country');

  // Function to handle change in country selection
  function handleCountryChange(event) {
    const countryValue = event.target.value;
    const stateElements = document.querySelectorAll('#state, [id$="-State"]'); // Selects all states including generic and form specific
    const stateBlockElements = document.querySelectorAll('#state-block, [id$="-State-Block"]'); // Selects all state blocks

    if (countryValue === "US") {
      stateBlockElements.forEach(element => element.style.display = "block");
      stateElements.forEach(element => element.value = null);
    } else {
      stateBlockElements.forEach(element => element.style.display = "none");
      stateElements.forEach(element => {
        element.required = false;
        element.selectedIndex = 0;
        element.value = "-";
      });
    }
  }

  // Attach event listener to any country dropdowns with ID 'country' or ending with '-Country'
  document.querySelectorAll('#country, [id$="-Country"]').forEach(countryElement => {
    countryElement.addEventListener('change', handleCountryChange);
  });

  // Webflow specific code to add states to forms listed in the array
  let forms = [
    "Start-Free-Trial", "Main-Form", "Nav-Get-a-Demo", "Primary-CTA-Free-Trial", 
    "Primary-CTA-Get-a-Demo", "Contact-Page", "Featured-Resource", "Whitepaper-Resource", 
    "Resource-Page", "Specific-Event-Form", "Specific-Resource"
  ];

  Webflow.push(function () {
    forms.forEach(form => {
      addCountries(form + "-Country");
      addStates(form + "-State");
    });
  });

  // Attach event listeners to all country dropdowns related to the forms listed
  forms.forEach((form) => {
    const countrySelector = `#${form}-Country`;
    document.querySelectorAll(countrySelector).forEach(countryElement => {
      countryElement.addEventListener("change", handleCountryChange);
    });
  });
var form = document.getElementById("main_form_2");
var url = window.location.pathname;
if (form){
  var field = form.querySelector("#Message");
  if(url === "/contact") {
    field.classList.remove('hidden')
  }else{
    field.value = "-"
    console.log("field.value", field.value)
  }
}

$('#current_url').val(window.location.pathname);
  
</script>

<script>
  const now = new Date();
  const dateTimeString = now.toISOString();
  $('form').each(function() {
   for (let param of params) {
    let paramData = urlParams.get(param) || localStorage.getItem(param) || "-";
 
     $(this).append($('<input>').attr({
      type: 'hidden',
      name: param,
      value: paramData
    }));
    
}
    $(this).append($('<input>').attr({
      type: 'hidden',
      name: 'currentDateTime',
      value: dateTimeString
    }));
    
    const formId = $(this).find('#form-identifier').attr('data-id');
    if(formId){
      $(this).append($('<input>').attr({
        type: 'hidden',
        name: 'form_id',
        value: formId
      }));
    }
  });
  
$('.form-label.focus-in').removeClass('focus-in');

$('.text-input, .select-field').on('focusin', function() {
  $(this).siblings('.form-label').addClass('focus-in');
});

$('.text-input, .select-field').on('focusout change', function() {
  $(this).siblings('.form-label').toggleClass('focus-in', $(this).val() !== '');
});
</script>
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/gsap/3.11.4/gsap.min.js"></script>

<script>
let menuLink = $(".nav-dropdown-link");
let content = $(".nav-hover-2");
let menuBG = $(".nav-menu-bg-2");
let dropdownWrap = $(".nav-content-2");
let menuArrow = $(".nav-arrow-wrap");
content.hide()
menuBG.css("overflow","hidden");

gsap.defaults({
  duration: .3
});

function revealDropdown(currentLink, currentContent) {
  dropdownWrap.css("display", "flex");
  gsap.set(menuArrow, {
    width: currentLink.outerWidth(),
    x: currentLink.offset().left
  });
  gsap.set(menuBG, {
    width: currentContent.outerWidth(),
    height: currentContent.outerHeight()
  });
  gsap.set(content, {
    opacity: 0
  });
  gsap.set(currentContent, {
    opacity: 1,
    x: "0em"
  });
}

function switchDropdown(currentLink, previousContent, currentContent) { 
  gsap.to(menuArrow, {
    width: currentLink.outerWidth(),
    x: currentLink.offset().left
  });
  gsap.to(menuBG, {
    width: currentContent.outerWidth(),
    height: currentContent.outerHeight()
  });
  // invert moveDistance if needed
  let moveDistance = 10;
  if (currentContent.index() < previousContent.index()) {
    moveDistance = moveDistance * -1;
  }
  gsap.fromTo(
    previousContent,
    { opacity: 1, x: "0em" },
    {
      opacity: 0,
      x: moveDistance * -1 + "em",
      duration: .15,
        onComplete: () => {
            previousContent.hide()
        }
    }
  );
  gsap.fromTo(
    currentContent,
    { opacity: 0, x: moveDistance + "em" },
    {
      opacity: 1,
      x: "0em",
      duration: .15
    }
  );
}

let showDropdown = gsap.timeline({
  paused: true,
  onReverseComplete: () => {
    dropdownWrap.css("display", "none");
    menuLink.removeClass("active");
  }
});
showDropdown.from(dropdownWrap, { opacity: 0, rotateX: -10, duration: 0.2 }).to(menuArrow, { opacity: 1, duration: 0.2 }, "<");

menuLink.on("mouseenter", function () {
  menuBG.show()
  let previousLink = menuLink.filter(".active").removeClass("active");
  let currentLink = $(this).addClass("active");
  let previousContent = content.filter(".active").removeClass("active");
  let currentContent = content.eq($(this).index()).addClass("active");

    if(previousContent.length > 0 && currentContent[0] != previousContent[0]){
      setTimeout(function() {
        previousContent.hide();
      }, 150);
    }
	currentContent.show()

  showDropdown.play();
  if (previousLink.length === 0) {
    revealDropdown(currentLink, currentContent);
  } else if (previousLink.index() !== currentLink.index()) {
    switchDropdown(currentLink, previousContent, currentContent);
  }
});

$(".primary-nav-links").on("mouseleave", function () {
  showDropdown.reverse();
});

</script>
<script>
        // List of blocked email domains
        const blockedDomains = [
            "gmail.com",
  "hotmail.com",
  "yahoo.com",
  "outlook.com",
  "icloud.com",
  "protonmail.com",
  "qq.com",
  "163.com",
  "me.com",
  "comcast.net",
  "aol.com",
  "hotmail.co.uk",
  "yahoo.co.uk",
  "live.com",
  "mail.com",
  "email.com",
  "msn.com",
  "yahoo.fr",
  "naver.com",
  "gmx.com",
  "mail.ru",
  "verizon.net",
  "ymail.com",
  "hotmail.fr",
  "artlover.com",
  "btinternet.com",
  "att.net",
  "orange.fr",
  "yandex.com",
  "googlemail.com",
  "bk.ru",
  "web.de",
  "yandex.ru",
  "outlook.fr",
  "rambler.ru",
  "free.fr",
  "wp.pl",
  "foxmail.com",
  "hotmail.it",
  "wanadoo.fr",
  "t-online.de",
  "live.co.uk",
  "my.com",
  "yahoo.co.in",
  "live.fr",
  "live.nl",
  "rocketmail.com",
  "yahoo.ca",
  "tom.com",
  "libero.it",
  "yeah.net",
  "139.com",
  "hotmail.de",
  "temple.edu",
  "earthlink.net",
  "rediffmail.com",
  "live.com.au",
  "hotmail.ca",
  "yahoo.gr",
  "yahoo.it",
  "yahoo.com.au",
  "yahoo.com.br",
  "virginmedia.com",
  "fastmail.com",
  "sudomail.com",
  "talktalk.net",
  "yaho.com",
  "yahoo.es",
  "myself.com",
  "outlook.pt",
  "live.cl",
  "windstream.net",
  "ya.ru",
  "yahoo.com.sg",
  "hanmail.net",
  "gmx.at",
  "fake.com",
  "outlook.de",
  "gmx.fr",
  "yahoo.com.tw",
  "live.ie",
  "hotmail.nl",
  "hotmail.be",
  "outlook.co.id",
  "gmx.net",
  "yahoo.de",
  "fastmail.fm",
  "mydomain.com",
  "mailbox.org",
  "sprintmail.com",
  "outlook.it",
  "gmx.co.uk",
  "outlook.jp",
  "list.ru",
  "live.ca",
  "live.de",
  "gmail.ru",
  "mail.fr",
  "operamail.com",
  "africamail.com",
  "live.dk"
        ];

        // Function to check if an email belongs to a blocked domain
        function isBlockedDomain(email) {
            const domain = email.split('@')[1];
            return blockedDomains.includes(domain);
        }

        // Function to handle email input
        function handleEmailInput(event) {
            const email = event.target.value;
            const errorMessage = event.target.nextElementSibling;
            if (isBlockedDomain(email)) {
                errorMessage.style.display = 'block';
                event.target.setCustomValidity('Please use a business email.');
            } else {
                errorMessage.style.display = 'none';
                event.target.setCustomValidity('');
            }
        }

        // Function to handle form submission
        function handleFormSubmission(event) {
            const emailInputs = event.target.querySelectorAll('input[type="email"]');
            let formIsValid = true;
            emailInputs.forEach(input => {
                const email = input.value;
                if (isBlockedDomain(email)) {
                    const errorMessage = input.nextElementSibling;
                    errorMessage.style.display = 'block';
                    formIsValid = false;
                }
            });
            if (!formIsValid) {
                event.preventDefault();
            }
        }

        // Attach event listeners to all email inputs and forms on the page
        document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', () => {
            const emailInputs = document.querySelectorAll('input[type="email"]');
            emailInputs.forEach(input => {
                // Create an error message element
                const errorMessage = document.createElement('div');
                errorMessage.className = 'error-message';
                errorMessage.textContent = 'Please use a business email';
                input.insertAdjacentElement('afterend', errorMessage);

                // Add event listener
                input.addEventListener('input', handleEmailInput);
            });

            // Attach submit event listener to all forms
            const forms = document.querySelectorAll('form');
            forms.forEach(form => {
                form.addEventListener('submit', handleFormSubmission);
            });
        });
</script>


<script>
function updateLink(containerId, newHref) {
    const container = document.getElementById(containerId);
    if (container) {
        const dropdownToggle = container.querySelector('.navbar12_dropdown-toggle');
        if (dropdownToggle) {
            // Create a new anchor element
            const newLink = document.createElement('a');
            newLink.href = newHref;
            
            // Copy attributes from the dropdown toggle to the new link
            for (let i = 0; i < dropdownToggle.attributes.length; i++) {
                const attr = dropdownToggle.attributes[i];
                newLink.setAttribute(attr.name, attr.value);
            }
            
            // Copy the inner content
            newLink.innerHTML = dropdownToggle.innerHTML;
            
            // Replace the dropdown toggle with the new link
            dropdownToggle.parentNode.replaceChild(newLink, dropdownToggle);
        }
    }
}

// Call the function for each link
updateLink('products-link', '/products');
updateLink('resource-link', '/resources');
updateLink('company-link', '/company');
updateLink('partner-link', '/partners');
</script>


<script>
  // This script adds rel="noopener noreferrer" to all external links that open in a new tab (target="_blank")
  // Internal links (same domain) are excluded.

  document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function () {
    const links = document.querySelectorAll('a[target="_blank"]');
    const currentHostname = window.location.hostname;

    links.forEach(link => {
      try {
        const linkHostname = new URL(link.href).hostname;

        // Skip if the link is internal
        if (linkHostname === currentHostname) return;

        // Get existing rel attribute or set to empty string
        let rel = link.getAttribute('rel') || '';

        // Add 'noopener' if not present
        if (!rel.includes('noopener')) rel += ' noopener';

        // Add 'noreferrer' if not present
        if (!rel.includes('noreferrer')) rel += ' noreferrer';

        // Set the updated rel attribute
        link.setAttribute('rel', rel.trim());
      } catch (e) {
        // Handle invalid URLs (e.g., mailto links)
        console.warn('Invalid URL:', link.href);
      }
    });
  });
</script>




<p id="twitter-share-text" fs-socialshare-element="content" style="display: none;">Check out this article by Darktrace: </p>



<script>
   
  function shareToLinkedIn(btn, link) {
    btn.setAttribute('target', '_blank');
    btn.setAttribute(
        'href',
        `https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=${link}`
    );
    btn.setAttribute('rel', 'noreferrer noopener');
}

    function socialShare(platform, btn, link) {
         if (platform === 'facebook') {
             shareToFacebook(btn, link);
         } else if (platform === 'twitter') {
             shareToTwitter(btn, link);
         } else if (platform === 'linkedin') {
             shareToLinkedIn(btn, link);
         }
     
    }
    
    // social sharing
    const btns = {
        'linkedin': document.querySelector('[data-social="linkedin"]'),
        'twitter': document.querySelector('[data-social="twitter"]')
    }

    const link = window.location.href;

    for (let key in btns) {
        if (btns.hasOwnProperty(key)) {
            socialShare(key, btns[key], link);
        }
    }
    
   </script>

<script>
document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function () {
    function insertCTA(retries = 0) {
        let blogCta = document.querySelector('.blog-cta-report');
        if (!blogCta) {
            if (retries < 5) { // Prevents infinite retry loops
                console.warn(`CTA element not found. Retrying... (${retries + 1}/5)`);
                setTimeout(() => insertCTA(retries + 1), 500);
            } else {
                console.error("CTA element not found after multiple attempts.");
            }
            return;
        }

        // Hide the original CTA so it doesn't appear twice
        blogCta.style.display = 'none';

        document.querySelectorAll('.text-rich-text.is-blog').forEach(block => {
            let placeholders = [...block.getElementsByTagName("p")].filter(p => p.textContent.includes("[related-resource]")); // Uses textContent for security

            // Limit to inserting only 2 CTAs if multiple placeholders exist
            placeholders.slice(0, 2).forEach(placeholder => {
                let clonedCTA = blogCta.cloneNode(true);
                clonedCTA.style.removeProperty('display');
                clonedCTA.style.removeProperty('visibility');
                clonedCTA.classList.remove("w-condition-invisible");
                clonedCTA.classList.add("w-condition-visible");

                placeholder.replaceWith(clonedCTA);
            });
        });
    }

    // Run after Webflow scripts initialize
    window.Webflow ||= [];
    window.Webflow.push(insertCTA);
});
</script>


<script>
window.
dataLayer = window.
dataLayer || [];
window.
dataLayer.push({
'event': 'content_grouping',
'content_group': ['Network']
});
</script>
<script src="https://hubspotonwebflow.com/assets/js/form-124.js" type="text/javascript" integrity="sha384-bjyNIOqAKScdeQ3THsDZLGagNN56B4X2Auu9YZIGu+tA/PlggMk4jbWruG/P6zYj" crossorigin="anonymous"></script></body></html>
